data.title: The Shanghai Cobra (1945)
data.meta_description: Someone is attempting to steal radium stored in a bank. Death by cobra venom connects a number of murders. Charlie Chan investigates.
data.text:
Phil Karlson’s crime comedy drama. Charlie Chan (Sidney Toler) investigates as someone is trying to pickpocket radium kept in a bank and demise by cobra venom links several killings.

After a prominent New York City banker is seemingly killed by the bite of a cobra, cop inspector Harry Davis (Walter Fenner) gets in touch with noted private sleuth Charlie Chan (Sidney Toler), who had formerly tangled with a murderer who used cobras as murder weapons.

Entering Manhattan with his faithful son, Tommy (Benson Fong), and taxi driver, Birmingham Brown (Mantan Moreland), Charlie is drawn into a complicated scheme embroiling a top-secret administration nuclear reserve being held at the victim’s bank.

Sidney Toler gives a good performance reprising his role as…

For the first ten minutes of the film it feels like director Phil Karlson is practicing for his two classic tough crime films a decade later, Kansas City Confidential and The Phenix City Story with its mysterious going-ons, dark shadows, a seeming femme fatale, a murder, a talking juke box, a lonesome coffee shop and more - but then after this very intriguing beginning it turns into a Charlie Chan film when the Honolulu cop is brought in. Not that that is a bad thing as this is a very decent Chan film.

Chan flies in at the request of a police friend who used to be on the beat with him years before. Thankfully, Charlie brings along Benson Fong…
